head.title: A Search for That First House

hedline.hl1: A Search for That First House

abstract.p: Helen Paxton letter says finding an affordable first house (May 28 article) is not so hard if one is willing to live in an integrated community like Montclair, NJ

block.p: I read the article on finding an affordable home [''A Yearlong Search for That First House,'' May 28] with not a little cynicism. Having recently sold and bought a home in a town 15 miles from New York, I can report that if one is not prejudiced about neighborhoods (and has a like-minded real estate agent) good values in nice older homes are to be found, at least in Essex County, N.J.

We moved from New York City to Montclair 13 years ago and bought a nice three-bedroom house with a lovely yard in a good neighborhood that is predominantly African-American (we are not). We recently sold this house for under $200,000, knowing full well that were it in a predominantly white neighborhood in our town it would have sold for at least $50,000 more.

Having recently sold and bought a home in a town 15 miles from New York, I can report that if one is not prejudiced about neighborhoods (and has a like-minded real estate agent) good values in nice older homes are to be found, at least in Essex County, N.J.

We moved from New York City to Montclair 13 years ago and bought a nice three-bedroom house with a lovely yard in a good neighborhood that is predominantly African-American (we are not). We recently sold this house for under $200,000, knowing full well that were it in a predominantly white neighborhood in our town it would have sold for at least $50,000 more.

We now live in a beautiful five-bedroom Victorian, which we got for well under $300,000. It's on a lovely street in a neighborhood that is heavily interracial. There are house values for people with open minds about who their neighbors might be.
HELEN PAXTON Director of Communications Rutgers Newark
